title: 111_hr4553
content:
The "21st Century Buy American Act" may be cited as the short title of this Act. Grants will be provided to domestic manufacturers. The Secretary of Commerce is authorized to establish a grant program for eligible U.S. manufacturers under specific criteria, including producing nonavailable items or being the last manufacturer in the country facing hardship. The grant program established by the Secretary of Commerce provides funding up to $5,000,000 for eligible U.S. manufacturers. Eligible entities can use the grant for increasing competitiveness for government contracts or production of nonavailable items. To receive a grant under this section, an eligible entity must meet certain criteria such as increasing production capacity for national security items, creating jobs, modernizing manufacturing facilities, or covering costs for adjustment assistance under the Trade Act of 1974. No funds can be used for profits of the eligible entity. An eligible entity must submit an application to the Secretary of Commerce with specific information to receive a grant under this section. The application should include details on the expected creation or retention of domestic jobs. The Secretary evaluates grant recipients annually to determine fund allocation. The term "nonavailable item" refers to items deemed unavailable under the Buy American Act. The Buy American Act prohibits items that are not mined, produced, or manufactured in the US in sufficient quantities or quality, have been waived under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009, or are listed as nonavailable articles in the Federal Acquisition Regulation. SEC. 3. REQUIREMENTS RELATING TO CERTAIN WAIVERS OF BUY AMERICAN ACT. Special Rules Relating to Certain Waivers under the Buy American Act, Section 2 is amended to include rules for use outside the United States without urgency or regular basis, with cost analysis required before entering into a contract. The Buy American Act now includes rules for waivers for use outside the United States, with cost analysis required before entering into a contract to compare costs from US manufacturers and manufacturers outside the US. The head of a Federal agency must consider the effects on domestic employment when granting waivers. The Buy American Act now requires consideration of short and long-term effects on US employment when granting waivers for use outside the US. Articles, materials, or supplies must be predominantly made in the US to qualify under the Act. The Buy American Act requires that the domestic components of articles, materials, or supplies must exceed 60 percent of the total cost to qualify under the Act. SEC. 4. TRANSPARENCY REQUIREMENTS.

Each agency applying an exception to the Buy American Act must notify the Director of OMB and provide details of the procurement and exception used. The Director of OMB must post this notification on a public website within 7 days. The term "agency" is defined as per section 551 of title 5, United States Code.

SEC. 5. REQUIREMENT FOR ANNUAL REPORT BY COMPTROLLER GENERAL ON EXCEPTIONS TO BUY AMERICAN ACT AND OTHER DOMESTIC SOURCE REQUIREMENTS. The Comptroller General of the United States must submit a report to Congress within 60 days after the end of a fiscal year on acquisitions made by each agency of articles, materials, or supplies purchased from entities outside the United States. The report should include the dollar value of items manufactured outside the U.S. and a list of waivers granted under the Buy American Act. The report to Congress must include the dollar value of items purchased from entities outside the U.S. and a list of waivers granted under the Buy American Act or other relevant laws. The Comptroller General must provide a report to Congress detailing procurement funds spent on goods from domestic and foreign sources, with exceptions for the intelligence community. The report must be made publicly available. The term "agency" in this section refers to an element of the intelligence community as specified in the National Security Act of 1947.
